Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: How Temporal Fluctuations Alter Indirect Interactions in Duckweed-based Communities and its Integration with a Student Report Exchange
Award.AbstractNarration:
Food webs reflect the interactions among species and the resources that they are eating, typically other species. Direct interactions in food webs, those between a consumer and its prey, play key roles in determining the dynamics of species in a community. Indirect interactions, resulting from impacts through intermediary species, may not be immediately apparent but may be as important as direct interactions. Climate models predict that environmental variability may increase in many areas due to, for example, a greater frequency of intense storm events and droughts. The impact of increased environmental variability on the importance of indirect interactions in food webs will be studied by developing and testing food web models. Experimental tests of food web theory will be conducted using a duckweed-based community. Duckweeds are small, floating, aquatic plants, and community members include insects that eat duckweed and predators of those insects. Environmental fluctuations will be created by varying temperatures. Refining general theory through the use of the duckweed communities will provide enhanced understanding of how environmental fluctuations might alter other systems of interest which cannot be so easily manipulated.

The broader impacts of this study will include a distributed experimental design among diverse elementary school classrooms in which each classroom will be an environmental replicate in a duckweed-based research project. In addition, student-designed duckweed projects at the elementary level and at the college level will be exchanged via an internet database to expand students' participation in a peer-exchange, inquiry-based approach to learning the science.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed the consequences of temporal fluctuations for food web interactions. We used a duckweed community with its associated duckweed species and herbivorous insects as an empirical system in which to examine the consequences of fluctuations. We parameterized a model of a duckweed-aphid system by including age-structure and fitting a temperature-dependent function for critical growth and maturity parameters. However, while examining the consequences of temporal fluctuations in small duckweed-based food webs, it became apparent that the discipline lacks an understanding of even the consequences of temporal fluctuations for a single-species growth rate. We demonstrated the degree to which this is qualitatively predictable, but quantitatively remains a challenge. In addition we examined broader implications of variation in consumers and resources. Basic theory examined the conditions in which consumer-resource dynamics can be simplified while additional theory examined conditions in which classic models oversimplify phenotypic variation. Empirical work examined the influence of spatial variation in nematode-switchgrass communities and the importance of propagules across space in agricultural weeds. Students at multiple levels of education were introduced to duckweed as an approachable and valuable system in which to ask basic ecological questions. Intensive integration in grade 8 classrooms refined our approach. Teaching workshops reached out to instructors across the K-12 system. A computer platform was developed for college-level investigations which created a digital journal through which students shared their investigations on duckweed across the class, across years, and across schools.


Last Modified: 05/31/2016
Modified by: Chad E Brassil

We parameterized a model of a duckweed-aphid system by including age-structure and fitting a temperature-dependent function for critical growth and maturity parameters. However, while examining the consequences of temporal fluctuations in small duckweed-based food webs, it became apparent that the discipline lacks an understanding of even the consequences of temporal fluctuations for a single-species growth rate. We demonstrated the degree to which this is qualitatively predictable, but quantitatively remains a challenge. In addition we examined broader implications of variation in consumers and resources. Basic theory examined the conditions in which consumer-resource dynamics can be simplified while additional theory examined conditions in which classic models oversimplify phenotypic variation. Empirical work examined the influence of spatial variation in nematode-switchgrass communities and the importance of propagules across space in agricultural weeds. Students at multiple levels of education were introduced to duckweed as an approachable and valuable system in which to ask basic ecological questions. Intensive integration in grade 8 classrooms refined our approach. Teaching workshops reached out to instructors across the K-12 system. A computer platform was developed for college-level investigations which created a digital journal through which students shared their investigations on duckweed across the class, across years, and across schools.
